page.title: 04Canal Inspector - Watford.
page.content: Mr Patterson lives in a cottage at lock 72 on the Grand Union Canal. He works for the Waterways Board as an Inspector. He started at 15 as a carpenter. In 1939/45 he fought in the war then he returned to canal work. Lock keepers are now called lengthsmen. Mr Patterson is now an inspector. He looks after 5-7 miles of canal. He works for 39 hours a week. The lengthsman, formally known as the lock-keeper, checks to see if the banks are safe and the locks navigable. As Inspector he has office work to do in Hemel Hempstead. The canal nowadays is used only for pleasure and fishing. There are no commercial boats now. It is too expensive. The lorry is much faster and cheaper for carrying goods. In the past the narrow boats carried wheat, coal, copper, corn, sand, and sugar.
